<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Analysis page: Bad performance
username_0: ## Where to find the issue
- https://www.coronawarn.app/de/analysis/
- https://www.coronawarn.app/en/analysis/

## Describe the issue
The analysis page is very unresponsive and slow. 
Here's a video: 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67682506/135767003-2d5e380f-e9ca-4f1f-a2df-b020a7769dce.mp4
<issue_comment>username_1: @username_0 Thanks for reporting. @username_3 FYI. Any proposals how to approach this issue? Thanks.
<issue_comment>username_2: @username_0 
For performance issues it's good to have an actual measurement, like you click on a certain button and it took a measured amount of time to produce a result.
If you have the current value, then you should specify the maximum expected value that you would consider acceptable.

Finally it would be good to know what system you were using and what the network parameters were.

---
I timed what I saw you doing in the video on a Windows 10 system with Google Chrome and a measured download internet connection speed of 38.8 Mbps.

On the page https://www.coronawarn.app/de/analysis/ I clicked on "Gesamter Zeitraum" with "TÃ¤glich" selected and it took 2.2 seconds to re-display all graphs. I had to set the zoom to 50% so I could see all graphs at once.

I found that speed acceptable, but of course your measurements and expectations may be different.
<issue_comment>username_2: @username_0 
Using browser developer tools it seems that the action you were taken is just redrawing the graphs without using any network connection, so that will probably depend on the processing power of your system. It will be interesting to see the response from @username_3 in any case.
<issue_comment>username_0: True, I just used the developer tools myself and yes, indeed there is no more downloading of any numbers going on once on the page. 
I recorded another video, this time with the "AktivitÃ¤tsanzeige" open on the other half of the display (the quality is really bad as GitHub limits file uploads to 10MB, sorry. Below is a zip were you can find the uncompressed video):

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67682506/135857046-ba616fb0-2687-4d71-a5ba-901f5acf3501.MP4

As you can see, coronawarn.app is sometimes responsible for nearly all of the processing done by the CPU. I'm very sure that there can be done something to enhance this, viewing the page on older devices must be very slow currently! 

---

Zip with the video:
[Slow.mov.zip](https://github.com/corona-warn-app/cwa-website/files/7278210/Slow.mov.zip)
<issue_comment>username_3: The bad performance comes from the apexchart DOM rendering task. Especially Safari is on this task really slow, i measured time up to 15s on my Safari. The rendering time increases with the data points. The longer the period, the longer the graphs will take to render. That is not a bug, it is the normal behavior if the page.
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_3 

Ah, okay! Thanks for the explanation! Not only Safari has this problem, but Microsoft Edge (Chromium based) is also very slow.

Is there any alternative or any improvement possible here? 
Because, sad to say, but the normal user will not wait more than ca. 10 sec. for the graphs to show up, if it just shows loading the normal user assumes somethings broken and leaves the page. ðŸ˜…
<issue_comment>username_4: @username_0 you could show an explaining text after some secs
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_4 

Would be one option, however, normal users will still not wait for more than ca. 15 sec. (I assume).
In general it's really sad that this is the intended behavior, if it's already slow on my MacBook Air with a M1 chip, mid- or low-end devices must be very slow on displaying the pages content...
<issue_comment>username_4: Wouldn't it be an idea to create svg pictures to show instead for a locally generated graph? (Or even only as a placeholder?)
<issue_comment>username_0: Is there an alternative available? Because, e.g. I don't have any performance problems viewing [WHOs corona dashboard](https://covid19.who.int/).
<issue_comment>username_4: Btw for me (iOS 15.1 Public Beta 2; iPad Air 4; A14 Bionic; SFSafariViewController (parent process GitHub)) it's pretty fast. Weird, maybe there was an improvement with WebKit 15 (and macs don't got the new update yet)?

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: AsciiDoc: Add support for global document attributes
username_0: I'm helping to migrate the Okta developer blog from Jekyll to Hugo. We're using both Markdown and AsciiDoc and Jekyll renders AsciiDoc using the following plugins:

```
group :jekyll_plugins do
  gem 'jekyll-asciidoc'
  gem 'asciidoctor-rouge'
end
```

We have most things working in Hugo, but we've discovered (with the help of @username_1) that Hugo doesn't provide a way to pass configuration to an external helper command, like `asciidoctor`. Here's the code that executes Asciidoctor: https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/blob/master/helpers/content.go#L626-L650

This means I have to define global attributes in every `.adoc` file. For example:

```
:page-liquid:
:source-highlighter: rouge
:icons: font
```

It'd be great if Hugo had a way to pass attributes from the Hugo configuration to the `asciidoctor` command. According to Dan, we're losing a lot of power without that ability.
<issue_comment>username_1: Being able to pass global attributes is essential for using Asciidoctor properly (the `-a` flag). Related to this is the ability to specify extensions to load (the `-r` flag).

One option is to simply allow extra arguments for the asciidoctor to be specified in the Hugo configuration. This would give the user maximum flexibility while only requiring a very small change to Hugo. There are many such options a user may want to specify. See https://asciidoctor.org/man/asciidoctor/
<issue_comment>username_2: Would it make sense to extend the [markup configuration][1] feature to also accept Asciidoc global attributes?

[1]: https://gohugo.io/getting-started/configuration-markup/<issue_closed>

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Post GA Contributor enablement checklist
username_0: This issue will capture any improvements we'll want to make to the contributor workflow after GA as we'll be learning what is working / not work post GA.


Troubleshooting Guide? (lots of little things to get tripped up when contributing do we need to mitigate those?
Define the branching strategy and perhaps content contributions once approved automatically Deploy via a GH action:: Merge to Develop > PR to Main
How to work on large batches of content for product releases that canâ€™t be publicly worked on?
PR checks to enforce Markdown linting? 
If there are needs to do content experiments after GA:, can we empower & train the Docs Team to be able to conduct those with Split.io?
<issue_comment>username_0: @austin-schaefer ideas welcome.
<issue_comment>username_1: We are constantly running into issues relating to `SSR` when building the site locally.

### Steps to reproduce

1. `yarn`
2. ' yarn start`
3. Sometimes the build will succeed, but sometimes we get thrown an error like the one below:

`warn The path "/" errored during SSR.
 Edit its component
node_modules/@newrelic/gatsby-theme-newrelic/src/components/AnnouncementBanner.js:45:11 to resolve the
error.`
<issue_comment>username_0: @jerelmiller any thoughts on that issue @username_1 reported?
<issue_comment>username_1: I will mention that we can usually fix this by running the commands below, but it's really ineffcient to have to build the site, notice the build error, run the commands, and then rebuild. The entire process can take ~10-20 minutes at times.

`
rm -rf node_modules
yarn
yarn clean
yarn start
`
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_1 totally, that's the windows equivalent of `restarting the machine` ðŸ˜„<issue_closed>
